text: In contrast to the purely enhancer - dependent effect of cytokines such as TNF on the activity of the HIV regulatory region ( LTR ) , we observed that okadaic acid ( OKA ) activates HIV transcription through both the enhancer , responding to the factor NF-kappa B , and the promoter domain of the LTR .

The inducibility of HIV LTR - driven luciferase expression constructs in lymphoblastoid cells stimulated by OKA depended on both functional <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding elements and the ability of the TATA box to bind the protein TBP .

In both transformed and normal lymphocytes , OKA stimulation induced intense phosphorylation of the constitutively expressed <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein in the nucleus , a property of OKA not shared by TNF , phorbol ester , or <extra_id_0> PHA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> interleukin 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Responsiveness of LTR constructs deleted of kappa B elements to HIV <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression was increased upon OKA but not TNF stimulation .

Our results suggest that <extra_id_0> SP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation induced by OKA , a selective inhibitor of the serine - threonine phosphatase <extra_id_0> PP2A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , facilitates the formation of a transcription complex involving general transcription factors , HIV <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins .

text: The formation of this complex would increase , independently of an in synergy with NF-kappa B , the low basal activity of the HIV LTR observed in normal T lymphocytes .
